G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 1.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 1 and applicable Massachusetts common law.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: G.L. c. 186, § 14 provides, in pertinent part, that a landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by a tenant is liable for actual and consequential damages or three months’ rent, whichever is greater, plus costs and reasonable attorneys’ fees.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19\u201319A.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19–19A because the Premises are located in Lowell, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the causes of action arose within this court’s territorial jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7 127A.proposition: Under G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., residential dwellings must be maintained in a condition that is safe, clean, sanitary, and fit for human habitation, free from chronic dampness and related conditions that encourage mold or fungal growth.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Under G.L. c. 111, § 127A and the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., residential dwellings must be maintained in a condition that is safe, clean, sanitary, and fit for human habitation, free from chronic dampness and related conditions that encourage mold or fungal growth.

Section 410.750 of the State Sanitary Co.raw_text: Section 410.750 of the State Sanitary Code
Section 410.750 of the State Sanitary Co.proposition: Section 410.750 of the State Sanitary Code authorizes enforcement of these standards and recognizes that violations may render the dwelling unfit for human habitation; serious or repeated violations are evidence of material impairment of the tenant’s use of the premises.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff further seeks statutory interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 261, and such reasonable attorneys’ fees as may become applicable if Plaintiff later retains counsel, as allowed under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Plaintiff further seeks statutory interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B, costs of this action pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14 and G.L. c. 261, and such reasonable attorneys’ fees as may become applicable if Plaintiff later retains counsel, as allowed under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes, as a matter of statute and common law, a covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting a tenant’s right to peaceful, safe, and habitable use of the leased premises.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that “every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant” of quiet enjoyment and describes “quiet enjoyment” as the tenant’s right to be free from serious interferences that impair the character and value of the premises. It further ties this covenant to both common law and G.L. c. 186, § 14, and applies it in the context of unsanitary, unsafe, and uninhabitable flooding conditions, thereby supporting that Massachusetts residential tenancies include a statutory and common-law covenant protecting peaceful, safe, and habitable use.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with applicable building, housing, and sanitary codes, where such failures materially impair the character and value of the leased premises, may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction based on excessive noise from a bar operated on other premises leased by the same landlord, focusing on landlord-created conditions and control over another tenant’s activities. It does not discuss failures to comply with building, housing, or sanitary codes, nor does it tie code noncompliance to breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, it does not support the specific proposition that violations of such codes, materially impairing the premises, constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises in compliance with applicable building, housing, and sanitary codes, where such failures materially impair the character and value of the leased premises, may constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The court’s discussion of the covenant of quiet enjoyment focuses on the landlord’s failure to take reasonable measures to address criminal drug activity in common areas, not on failure to maintain code-compliant physical conditions. Earlier in the opinion, the court expressly cabins building, housing, and sanitary code issues within the warranty of habitability, not quiet enjoyment, and it does not state or imply that code violations that materially impair the premises constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment. The case therefore does not support the specific code-based formulation in the proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has held that statutory and regulatory violations that interfere with a tenant’s health or safety can constitute an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, but it does not hold that statutory or regulatory violations affecting health or safety are themselves sufficient to constitute unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. Instead, the Court holds that a violation of the lead paint statute "alone is not sufficient" and that a tenant must show at least negligent conduct plus landlord knowledge or reason to know of the condition. Thus, the case rejects the idea that a statutory health/safety violation by itself automatically establishes a § 14 violation.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: The implied warranty of habitability, while distinct from the covenant of quiet enjoyment, supports and informs the determination that serious sanitary code violations and unremediated conditions affecting health, such as mold, constitute a substantial interference with the tenant’s occupancy.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This excerpt is a concurrence/dissent that explicitly criticizes and narrows the majority’s implied warranty of habitability. The author argues that any implied obligation should be confined to compliance with statutory and code-based minimum standards, and does not discuss or link that warranty to the covenant of quiet enjoyment or to the concept of substantial interference with occupancy. Because it neither treats the relationship between warranty and quiet enjoyment nor uses the warranty to define substantial interference (e.g., from mold or similar health-related conditions), it does not support the proposition claimed.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The point at which I dissent from the opinion of the court is where it attempts to accomplish the first step by resort to an implied warranty of the fitness of the rented dwelling unit instead of by the implication of an agreement that the unit will comply with the minimum standards required therefor by law. … The court makes no attempt to define what is required to make a dwelling unit ‘fit for human occupation’ … It suggests that broad discretion be left to trial courts to decide these questions on a continuing case by case basis.”

Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: The implied warranty of habitability, while distinct from the covenant of quiet enjoyment, supports and informs the determination that serious sanitary code violations and unremediated conditions affecting health, such as mold, constitute a substantial interference with the tenant’s occupancy.
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns measurement of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in a subsidized tenancy and the interaction with Section 8 regulations. It does not analyze or rely on the relationship between the implied warranty of habitability and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss sanitary code violations or conditions like mold as constituting substantial interference with occupancy for quiet enjoyment purposes. The only mention of quiet enjoyment is procedural (the judge found a breach but awarded no damages to avoid duplication), so the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: “Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982). … Damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability are measured by ‘the difference between the value of the dwelling as warranted … and the value of the dwelling as it exists in its defective condition.’ … It is, after all, the tenant who suffers when conditions in an apartment violate the implied warranty of habitability.”

Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982).proposition: In cases of environmental or health-affecting conditions such as mold, improper ventilation, chronic dampness, or similar issues, courts have found that a landlord’s failure to repair after notice can constitute a breach of quiet enjoyment and warrant recovery of rent abatement and consequential damages.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982).support_reasoning: The case involves a serious rodent infestation (an environmental/health-related condition) and holds that the landlord’s failure to correct the defect after notice resulted in a substantial interference with the tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises, constituting a compensable loss of their leasehold rights. The tenants recovered multiple forms of monetary relief, including an amount equivalent to three months’ rent under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment (G.L. c. 186, § 14) and additional damages under G.L. c. 93A. Although the opinion focuses on rodents rather than mold or dampness specifically, it directly supports the proposition that failure to repair such conditions after notice can breach quiet enjoyment and justify rent-related and consequential damages.
Wolfberg v. Hunter, 385 Mass. 390 (1982).relevant_excerpt: We believe that the judge erred in thus resolving the issues raised by the plaintiff’s claim for damages. There has been a substantial interference with the use and enjoyment of the apartment to which the tenants were entitled under their lease. This interference with a right guaranteed to them under their lease constitutes a loss of property to the tenants. They had a contractual right to enjoy the use of the apartment free of rodents. The judge found that the tenants withheld rent justifiably. Thus they were deprived of their contractual right by the landlord’s conduct.
